sourceDesc.p: Translation of 陸機集十一卷 into English.

body.div:
Translated parts
This is a highly conventional defiantly prosaic start. *才士 is conventially polite way of referring to poets. *所作 "what they have created" is again demonstratively prosaic and plain. *觀 "look over, modern Chinese 翻" is neither 讀 "read", nor the purely visual "survey" here. 竊 is conventionally and politely self-effacing: "I flatter myself that..." *有以 "have what it takes to" not some je-ne-sais-quoi "something within me"; *得“get at" *用心 "what they were getting at, what they were (ultimately) trying to do" is analytic. 用心 is not an obvious expected term to use here. Luji goes on to explain himself. "use of mind" would be an irrelevantly literal translation. *夫 "as a matter of fact, generally" marks the taking breath before a heavy non-narrative statement. *放言 "give free rein to their verbalisations" must be compared to the early 放心 "give free rein to one's mind" from Mencius. This is a dramatic way of talking, but perhaps not as provocatively informal as "let loose". *LJ 觀s the literature with empathy for the conditions of their production. *遣辭 "put forward/send forth into life formulations" conjoins a perhaps alternative way of looking at literary text. *The whole line is a temporal subordinate clause marked by the particle 其. *After 夫其 we have a QUADRISYLLABIC sequence. 良 is informally intensitive "pretty (many), quite (a lot)". *變 "(often abrupt or radical) change> substantial literary variation" is a core term here. 妍蚩 is poetic and obsolescent. *好惡 hàowù "what one likes and dislikes" offers EPEXEGETIC "relief" to what precedes, and the inverse word order 好惡妍蚩 would be unacceptable. Both phrases are nominalised. 可得 "may be V-ed" is possible because LJ has the 有以 "wherewithal" mentioned above. *言 is "to pronounce on", not just "talk about, speak of". 每 picks up the 每 in line 1 in what was to become 八股 conventional style. *自 "oneself ... ONE'S OWN object" must be read as a double reflexive "myself put together my own pieces". 其 understood. *屬 is unpretentious "put together" as opposed to 作 "create" or even 撰 "compose". 尤 "especially, paricularly" is not merely intensitive or emphatic. *見 "get to see> get to understand" METAPHORICAL is a success verb. 情 is "the underlying reality of this (creative) situation that I have just described", more than 實 "factual situation, facts of the matter". 患 "run into the problem" is not fear of something but exposure to a problem/danger. *意 is not philosophical "ideas men have" but autobiographic: "my ideas". *稱 refers to correspondence: "correspond properly, capture properly", not equality or balance. *物 refers not to things generally but to the things dealt with by one's 意 "ideas/notions". 文 is autobiographic: "my literary production". *逮 "catch up with (the higher realm of ideas" is dramatic and provides a semantic VARIATIO of the 稱 above. 蓋 is grammaticalised: "as far as I can see". 非 negates the whole predicate: "it is not a case of/because of NPab". *知之難 is "an intellectual difficulty nàn". 能之難 "a difficulty regarding my (inherent, not situational, creative) capacity". *也 has a large scope marking the sequence of two contrastive causative statements: "it is because". 故 "with all this in mind". *作 is past tense "I have created". The 序 is clearly done post festum, as Knechtges has it. 文賦 is not necessarily used here as the title of the work: "a poetic exposition on the matter of literary works". *述 Having spoken of himself creating 作 a moment ago, LJ hastens to add politely the more modest 述 "transmit" in his 竊－self-effacing mode. He indicates that he is essentially merely "transmitting" features of his predecessors. *先士 "predecessors", not "writers" must be compared with 先君 "former ruler". 因 "on this occasion" links into what precedes. *論 prototypically refers to prosaic discussion, here abstractly "take up the problems of" which can be done in poetic form. Note that LJ's 文 does not distinguish prose from poetry. *作文 is an original nominalisation "the creating of literary works". *利害 "what is helpful and harmful to the process of 作文. Neither (ultimate) success nor failure come into the picture at this point. *所由 "the sources of (what is conducive and harmful to literary production)." 他日 "some other time> one day". *殆 "perchance" is not about hope. *可謂 "(this work) will deserve to be considered". *曲 "down to the last remote detail". *妙 "intricate felicities (of successful literary works)" focusses on consciously uncontrollable felicitousness, which is far more profound than subtlety. 操斧 "axe in hand" is continuous and adverbial, not an inchoative VP. LJ assumes the reader is aware that he is using a literary work to deal with literature, on which theme there is this 典故 from the Book of Odes. The subject is the poet, "As it gets to the point where I hew an axe-handle, axe in hand." The statement is NOT a generalisation inserted here. 雖 "Maybe..., Even if..." *取則 "One may be choosing one's model" 取 must be translated. *不遠 "but (that model) is (in hand and) not far away". 若夫 "when it comes to..." establishes a new topic in an emphatic way common in Laozi and is not adversative. *隨手 "spontaneously arising (in the process of the creative process" looks like a colloqualism in this preface. 良 is REPETITIO of the conversational adverb already used above. *辭 "one's literary formulations" does not refer abstractly to "words" in general but to the linguistic repertoire at the poet's own disposal. 逮 "capture, catch up with" reverts to the felicitous word used just above. REPETITIO 蓋 "generally> by and large" *能言 "what I seem to be capable of expressing" is again in the self-effacing 竊－mode. 具 "I supply (completely) below." 佇 "position oneself, take a position in" is poetic, pregnant and expressive of an important aestetic pose of expectancy. The subject is LJ. *區 "realm, region" is abstract and refers to the (central) reference point of the poetic vision, not of things. *以 "so as to (be able to)" focusses on what the position central point from which things are viewed allows LJ, (or perhaps after all the poet in general?), to do. *玄 "mysteriously>with a focus on mysterious underlying realities" specifies the mystifying nature of the poetically analytic vision. *覽 "look over" is not optical but poetico-aesthetic. *What is dark are not physical objects, but the focus of the perspective. 頤 "shape on the basis of; imbue with" is highly poetic. *情志 "my most real poetic aspirations" 遵 is to "feel with and follow with" (unlike 從) *以 "and so" introduces a consequence of the 遵－ing with that poetic empathy. *歎 is psychologial: "be moved to sighs". 逝 is the passing not of the seasons by of beautiful things as time passes. The seasons/times as such are not poetically moving. 瞻 is "look at with appreciation", no need for any "peering on". *物 are primarily (but perhaps not exclusively) living creatures in contexts like this. *思 "concerned reflection" is appreciative rather than negatively brooding. 悲 is empathetic sadness, as opposed to 哀 "grief". *勁 "raging/mighty (autumn)" has nothing to do with virility or strength. 喜 is a quiet inner delight, no 樂 "public rejoicing". *條 "(small) twig" contrasts with 枝 "(larger) branch". *芳 describes not spring itself but the plants in spring. 心 "in his mind" 懍懍 being reduplicated, is figurative and intensitive; *懷 is here to feel what is physical with the innermost part of one's mind. "Take to heart" is excellent! 志 "(poetic) aspirations" contrasts with 意 "intentions; ideas". *眇 "far-reaching" is intensitive when reduplicated, and it contrasts 邈 "remote". *臨 is used abstractly as poetic for 近 "approach", no connotation of a downward direction in such contexts. 德 "untranslatable: charismatic power" is to do with ritual example and more broadly impact of exemplary ritual propriety. *駿 "imposing; supreme" connotes not light in itself. 先人 stylistically often elevated and formal "father", is here general plural "forebears". *清 "immaculate purity; impeccability", here adjectival, relates to ritual propriety. *芬 is "aesthetic fragrance of propriety" 府 "treasure house" is epexetic to the figurative 林 " 'forest' ", can be wild and extensive, on mountains and in inaccessible regions, as distinct from 楚 "copse, grove" 麗藻 refers litterally to the nicely balanced out naturally wild weed, and by METAPHORA to the literary production of the ages. *彬彬 "dignified elegance" has nothing lovely. The nominalised reduplicated binome is interesting. These deserve to be collected, perhaps also specically as nnab.post-N. 投 "throw" is dramatic, unlike 釋 in the meaning "put aside". *篇 "chapters>texts" is generic and fails to show respect for the classical works. *援 "pick up", as opposed to 取 "take" is literary and typically applies also to musical instruments. 聊 "so as to, in order to" is solemn and literary, as opposed to 以. *宣 "proclaim", as opposed to 表 "manifest", focusses on explicit articulation directed at an audience. *斯文 "this our literary heritage" is a solemn complex allusion that takes the expression to mean specifically what it does not mean in the Analects or in Shiji. 也 marks a topic "at its/the beginning". 皆 "exclusively" makes it expicit that nothing other than 收視 and 反聽 is happening. *收視 “look receptively" contrasts with looking out for something. *反聽 "listen to oneself listening" is hypersensitive poetic listening as opposed to info-accumulating listening. 耽思 "meditate with obsessive abandon" holds nuances of addictive poetic reflection rather than 慮 "thinking". 傍 is "explore things, pursuing tangential associations in all directions" as opposed to 求 "seeking something particular (in all directions)" 精 is "subtle poetic/creative spirit", as opposed to 性 "nature" or 情 "essential feelings>essence". *(Note that unlike 心 the word 精 is not very commonly used as an adverb.) *騖 "race along", is more often ethereal and figurative than 馳 "gallop". *八極 "the eight bounds of the universe" relate not merely to 天下 "the sublunar world" but perhaps more to 宇宙 "the universe". The reach of the 心 "mind" is narrower than that of the more elevated 精 "subtle spirit". *萬 "myriads" as opposed to 萬 "10 000". *It does not matter that 仞 are probably almost three yards: 萬仞 refers to a vast vertical depth, poetically. 致 "reach the acme or highest pitch" corresponds with 其始 above. 情 "underlying moods" must be carefully distinguished 物 "physical objects", not creatures. *昭晣 "glow intensely for one (with significance, as words may glow for one in poetic texts)". *進 "push each other forward into focus and bring each other in relief" 傾: what is "poured forth" are not the words, as one might expect, but the 瀝液 "scattered juices" that give a group of words their inner freshness. 漱 is "take in just to rinse one's poetic organ with (and spit out again!)" *六藝 "the corpus of the six prescribed texts". *芳 is figurative and olfactory aspect is merely metaphorical "exquisite". Sweetness is something else. 天淵 is "(the whole realm between high) Heaven and the deep abyss on earth below", the poet placing>viewing himself in the whole vast range of the universe, has a cosmic poetic perspective. *安 "find one's peace of mind/serenity in" is not a matter of physical resting but of peace of mind. *流 is Heraclitus's flux of things, not any local current. 濯 is a recherché poetic word: "delve/dip into". *下泉 "springs of the underworld" in this cosmological context. *泉 "spring" as opposed to 川 "stream". *潛浸 is dramatic and illicit: "wallow in". 於是 "At this high pitch of excitement...". *沈 is figurative "sunken> obsolete, long forgotten". *怫 is dramatic and involves a kind of psychologising personification of phrases: "with angry reluctance". *悅 "give poetic pleasure and satisfaction. 若 lays out explicitly the figurative mode in the last line. *游 is an empty epithet, like that in 飛鳥 which does not refer to "flying birds" but to birds prone to flying, capable of flying, but in the case at hand possible perching somewhere. * 藻 "figurative: literary flourishes" are personified and endowed with wings. *聯 "strung together": they come in flocks. *翩 "flutter by": must be appreciated in flight, cannot be fixed down and controlled. 若 lays out explicitly the figurative mode in the last line. 翰 "feathered" works like an empty Homeric epithet. 百 "countless", unlike 一百. *闕 "be missing, lack": the texts were perhaps neglected, but not omitted. 採 "pluck (like flowers)" is dramatic and lively. 謝 is to "reject" the all too obviously attractive morning blossom. 於 "in its state of (being aleady unfurled)" is a loose use of the word. 啓 "make a start with" answers the 已 above. *夕秀 is an evening beauty. *未振 at the stage where it has not yet displayed its beauty. 於須臾 could conceivably be "in (poetically) surveying one moment" not "in the course of one single moment". The poet would then all history poetically crystalised in the poetic vision of one moment. But this would be in unpoetic structural contrast with the clearly more plain corresponding line immediately below. 撫 is figurative "reach out to with one's mind" and involves no touching. 然後 "Then and only then..." is not "only at some time afterwards". *義 "overall point" is subtly different from 意 "idea, thought". *按 "based on" postmodifies, as opposed to 陳 "lay out, set out" *部 "(poetic) categories" are adhered to, as opposed to being put forward. 就班 "put in their proper place (as in a military formation)" is according to rhetorical and syntactic propriety. 抱景 "comport poetic vision" corresponds to the audible resonance below. *叩 "knock on to test" is poetically and figuratively dramatic on the creative process. 懷響 "what embodies (poetic) resonance (to the world)". *彈 "test by plucking". *咸 畢 "all": VARIATIO avoiding the ordinary 皆. 振 "shake off". 沿 "be carried along by". *而 "but". 之 "go to" is conative, as opposed to 至 "reach". 虎 is adverbial "like a tiger". *獸 is adverbial "like a wild beast". The subject continues to be the phrases: like dragons they appear like birds they drift off in all directions. The dramatisation continues. 者topicalises "that discouse attains its ends". *唯 "be just because". *曠 "(because it) expands the significance of words (and does not stay with their usual meaning)". 眇眾慮 "reflect meticulously on all one's deliberations" emphasises the second-order reflexive nature of poetic judgment which suffers from an embarras de richesse of deliberations (not here "cares"). *為言 "create (poetic) text" is different from 造字 "make words". 籠 "cage>encompass and domesticate" is dramatically figurative; *天地 does not refer specifically to Heaven and Earth but to everything within these, the universe. *形 refers to the concrete literary expression the poet has created for the purpose, and which he fixes as he creates the definitive text. 挫 "get the upper hand on", see 《莊子·天地》：“不以物挫志之謂完。” *於 "on" for the prosaically required 以 "with" is poetic and surprising. 於 "at" 於 "from". *流離 ALLITERATION. *翰 poetic usage for the sake of the rhyme. 立 causative and figurative "establish". *榦: 文榦. 文 is abstract: "literary/rhetorical/poetic patterning". *繁 "(poetic) variety/multiplicity". 信 "poetic empathetic truthfulness" consists in the inner reality and the outer appearance not being at variance." 故 "And so, (given this poetic empathetic truthfulness". *每“whenever”. *變 subjectless "there is a sudden change". *在顏 "it will manifest itself on the poet's face". 思 is the poet's thought. *涉 "touch upon" is figurative (HYDCD 涉及，關連). *必笑 the poet is easily moved to emotional reactions like laughter and sighing, and will actively express his feelings of delight (or of grief in the following line). 方 "as soon as". The poet is âme sensible, hyperreactive. (Indulgently sentimental, Horace would say, but that is a different story...) 或...或 "at times... at other times". *操 "wield" as opposed 持 "grasp; hold". 觚 "writing tablet" is stationary, as opposed to 簡 "bamboo strip". 含 figurative "retain, hold back" 含毫：比喩構思爲文或作畫. 邈然 is visual:short for HSWZ 邈然遠望. The image is of mouth and eyes. 事 is not an event but a process. The grammar is this: "The joy of this undertaking/artistic process". 固 modifies a nominal predicate and not 欽. 虛無 "the apparently insignificant" is 寂寞 is not abstract, but general: "what appears mute". *求音 is to try to get it to sing, poetically. 函 is heavily figurative: "encompass (poetically), as opposed to 包 "contain". 心 refers to the physical organ which is so small when compared to the torrent. No small size is attributed to the mind as such. 之 "non-specific: things" refers to the poet's preoccupation: thoughts/ideas. "Words give greater breadth to things/ideas." 思 "reflection" (to be distinguished from 意 "ideas, thoughts") presses thought/ideas to a deeper level. 芳 "fragrant" (not drooping) is an unsurprising word to use, almost poetically a little disappointing in collocation with the splendid 蕤. 發 "spread forth> make sensible", as opposed to 為 "produce". 燦 is provocatively obscure. 鬱雲 "dense clouds" are seen as productive of a violent profusion in the form of a creative thunderstorm. *翰林 perhaps GREAT CELEBRATED poets? This is not clear. 待考 體 "styles" of all kinds, the topic, are not only the prescribed or normative ones, of which there is no infinite variety; *萬 "all sorts of". *殊 "(subtle, hence so many) differences. 一 "one and the same". *量 "(physical, qualitative and aesthetic) dimension". 意 "poetic intent, idea/thought" takes administrative charge of 司 of the definitive text 契. 在有無 here "embroiled in the alternative whether expressions should be or should not be in the text"? ?. *僶俛 ALLITERATION and HOMOIOTELEUTON. 雖 "even at the risk of". *離 "diverge> offend against". 方 "standard category of the square". *圓 "standard category of the square". 窮 "exhaust the details of". *盡 "bring out completely. *相 "the characteristic physiognomy of things". 妥帖 "fit well together" ALLITERATION binome. 澄心 "purify the heart" is recurs elsewhere. *罄 "copletely" modifies both VPs that follow. 岨峿 is practically HAPAX LEGOMENON. 形 "forms" are found in the world, 狀 are the "images" created in art. This is not about mere "description". "(felicitous) phrasing demonstrates talent and shows skill". 淺深 "the alternative between being shallow or profound. HOMOIOTELEUTON. 不讓 "does not give up", i.e. insists on making a poetically responsible decision on what to choose
>
